ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to critically interpret and perform on the piano
I continued my development on the violin, focusing on relaxation and bow control.
Continued to improve my vocal technique.
improved ability to play clarinet and interpret pieces of music in order to play effectively and musically
I learned a lot about vocal technique  and increased my musicality abilities a lot. I also learned a bit about
How to play clarinet better.
Breathing, vocal health, vocal agility, support, increased range, confidence
I really improved my bow technique this semester, as well as learning two movements of the Bruch violin concerto.
I learned more about my instrument and how I can improve my technique and embouchure.
I developed a lot of new skills on the violin!
I developed technical and musical skills in my individual practicing.
great!

I took voice lessons for credit, and am so glad I did -- it added really wonderful structure to my semester and I learned a ton. There are lots of opportunities to sing as a Yale undergrad, and I was very grateful to find one that helped me actually improve technique!

I played the first movement of the Vieuxtemps Violin Concerto and the first four movements of the Bach D minor Partita this semester. I specifically worked on standing more still while I play (not "swooping") and getting rid of tension in my shoulders and upper right arm.
I broadened my knowledge and understanding of French piano music.
I worked on performance technique, collaboration with piano, right arm movement, shifting, and other violin technique work.
I learned how to be a better musician and person.
I was able to troubleshoot bad habits that I had developed, and I benefitted greatly from personal attention and different pedagogical tools.
I learned how to strengthen my breath support to get a more even vibrato while keeping my tongue in the right position.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I really value the opportunity to study with talented Yale School of Music students for free through the lessons for credit program, and I have greatly enjoyed my four semesters in the program. 

However, based on what I have heard, the teachers seem underpaid! I think that a raise should be considered as the teachers seem to be making far less money than what they would earn from private lessons.

The strength is that you get a very trained vocal coach from the School of Music and they have so much wisdom to offer. The weakness is that you dont get a lot of variety in terms of what type of music you get to sing which feels a bit restrictive.
I wish I had more help reading music because I still struggle with it a bit
The opportunity to have weekly one-on-one lessons is amazing.

Lessons were always clear on their objective and kept me engaged. Only thing I would improve on is letting the applicant be assigned to their teacher quicker, but that may have only been a problem for my instrument
I like the option of having different lesson plans to choose from.
n/a

Really, lessons are catered to you (the student) -- my teacher was incredibly skilled at figuring out what sort of help I needed most and structuring our lessons around that. The only weakness I can think of didn't have to do with teaching but just with communication -- I wish the information about the end-of-semester jury was made clearer earlier (i.e. how many pieces, how to prepare, etc.).
This course is great for the serious musician who would like to improve their playing and work with a very good teacher.

Strengths: I was given the opportunity to learn lots of new music that I maybe wouldn't have learned otherwise

Weaknesses: I would have appreciated more opportunities to select repertoire jointly, and I would have appreciated more opportunities to discuss the music in a more open and free-flowing way.
This course is very strong. I think my studio could benefit from having one more studio class per semester.
It was wonderful.
There should be more flexibility in the types of music you can work on. Classical music is fine, but it really limits the relevance of the course as a lot of people want to sing other types of music.
I really liked how the lessons were weekly, as it gave me time to practice while still maintaining consistency.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!
I would recommend taking credit lessons to another student if they are passionate about their instrument, and already put in the time to practice throughout the week.

Yes, you should definitely take this class if you want to study musical performance for free at Yale, most likely with a graduate student. Do be aware that you will be required to take some music theory courses along with the lessons, though, and the extra one credit from lessons on your schedule can  artificially inflate your schedule load and make your dean less likely to approve your schedule. Your experience in this course will ultimately depend on your specific private teacher and on your dedication and commitment to your craft.

I definitely recommend for any singer regardless of skill level. You really learn very good technique that helps you improve pretty quickly and for most people, you get to sing in a style different from what youre used to.
Yes, it's super convenient.
Yes, it helps your singing and confidence soooo much!!

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The opportunity to take lessons with a Professor is incredible and I also loved the studio class performance setting where you got to know the other people in your studio, and also have the chance to practice performing what you have been working on.
I would recommend this course to anyone who loves music and their instrument. It was a very nice course and I hope that more people take the course.
Yes. If you want to take violin lessons at a high level, you should be taking lessons for credit. They are free and the instruction is very high quality.
Yes, if you are serious about music.
yes very fun learned alot
I would absolutely recommend lessons for credit. You will learn a lot, have time allotted to spend on music (yay!), and it's quite low-stress!
I would definitely recommend this course to another student.
Yes, any violinist/instrumentalist who is serious about studying and improving at their instrument should highly consider taking lessons.
Professor Purvis is a wonderful teacher.
I would recommend it if you're willing to put in the work!
Yes! It is a great opportunity to get personal feedback and grow as a singer.
